reviewTitle: This is a very nice device, and if you have any handiness with tools, easy to install on the wall.
reviewDescription: I have a 32 inch TV, and this accommodates it well, but I chose this wall mount because it will support a larger TV when I replace the one I am using now. The hardest part of installing this thing was finding the wooden framing behind my walls. Even with a stud-finder, it was a bit tricky.There is a list of tools needed to install this that do NOT come with it. Luckily I had all of those already on hand. If I had not, I might have been a bit annoyed, In addition to what is included in the box you need the stud finder if you are installing on a plasterboard and framed wall, a cordless drill with a 5/32' (4mm) bit, a manual Phillips-head screwdriver, A socket wrench and a 1/2 inch socket (12 or 13 mm), an awl or ice-pick, and a pencil.It would also be easier mount on the wall if you have a spare set of hands to keep the mount in place while you crank the top two lag bolts.NOW that it is installed I only have two very minor issues with it.1. The bars that attach to the television  stick up over the top of the set, which will no longe be an issue when I replace my little TV.2. The set pulls out and retracts very well, and tilts from side to side easily. However the vertical tilt has to be chosen and locked in. If you want to change it you have to loosen two bolts and then retighten them once you have moved the set to the preferred angle. It would require a sophisticated bit of machinery to overcome this, so for the price I can't really complain.In all this is a very functional television wall mount, and very sturdy if installed correctly.

This would get 5 stars if the back plate was about 18" wide instead of about 13".  Why you might ask...Well, install instructions tell you to mount the four corners on wooden studs when mounting to dry wall.  The problem is, in most residential constructions studs are 16" apart.  This mean, if you want to stud mount you have to get creative. Fortunately the back plate has two holes dead center which I used to stud mount and then I used heavy duty mollies to secure the corners.  This is not recommended or "suggested" in the mounting instructions and hardware to do this is not supplied.  While I am not an engineer, I believe this is wholly adequate and unless someone hangs from the TV, it is not going to get ripped off the wall.  That said, if you are not "handy" with these kind of things you might find the hanging instructions to be inadequate.  The install hardware does allow for fine tune leveling but if you hung the mount level in the first place, you won't need to use this.That said, the mount works great.  It is easy to articulate, forward, back as well as about 30 degrees left or right.  There is also the ability to tilt the screen a few degrees forward.  This can really help with minimizing reflection on the screen.Mounting issues aside, this is a great mount for the money...you should have no issues.PS - I am going to make the wires disappear after I mount the cabinet below the TV.
Easy to install, sturdy, maneuverable. Nothing more to ask for.
The mount sold is for the minimum size tv.  If you want to use it for any larger tvs that it supports, you have to buy the extended brackets!Otherwise it’s great, and sturdy!

No issue once it’s up.Ended up returning it thou.  Found another by the same brand I believe that is much closer to the wall although more expensive.Wound recommend if you don’t mind having it stick an inch or so more than the slim version

reviewTitle: seems sturdy, a couple minor gripes
reviewDescription: It seems like it's pretty heavy duty and the instructions were easy to follow. This was my first ever attempt at mounting a TV to the wall. I was trying to hang a 65" U8K by myself but wasn't sure why it wasn't connecting with the mount. I had a friend come help me and noticed the mount was tilting when trying to hang the TV. The tilt adjustment was totally loose, and nothing was mentioned in the manual about this. If I had known I had to tigthen/check the tightness of these screws before-hand that would have helped.Once I tightened those screws it was possible to actually hang the TV on the mount.The TV has a slight downward tilt, despite manual saying it should be parallel to the wall. I've adjusted the tilt as much as I can, but it still has some downward tilt. I think it may be because of the spacers.The manual for the U8K says to "use spacers", but doesn't specify how much spacing is required/suggested. It does however state that the screw length should be 9.5 mm - 11 mm. So based on this information I was trying to choose the combination of spacers and screws (plus the washer) that would get me there. The proper screws per the U8K manual are M6, so I didn't bother even looking at the other screws available with the mount. The closest possible arrangement for the 65" U8K in terms of spacers, screws and the washers is one of the 10 mm spacers and two of the 2.5 mm spacers, plus the washer and 35 mm M6 screw. This gets the numbers down to 13mm (excluding however thick the washer and bracket add). I'm not sure that much space is really needed, now that I see it on the wall. The TV has a little subwoofer on the back but there's now plenty of room for ventilation AND clearing the bump.Finally, while the hardware was fine, the allen wrench was Chinese garbage.

I’m sure they would send you new ones no questions asked, but imagine how inconvenient it would be if this happened to you the week before the Super Bowl & hopefully you didn’t expect a bunch of people over. They do sell extender supports for larger spacing, but it’s sold separately. So be prepared if you plan on buying a wall mount, but over all the mount itself seems good & really simple to setup based on how far I got before finding out I was “screwed” lol. I could have called them, got a bolt & the extender bars but when it would have all been said & done it would take me till Super Bowl weekend to get this mounted, so I just went to Best Buy and over paid for a larger wall mount.

reviewTitle: Small, with very little side-to-side adjustment
reviewDescription: It holds a TV but only has a small amount of left to right adjustment.  I couldn't mount it in the center of the wall due to having to mount it to a joist.  The plate that the TV sits on (after connecting the mounting brackets on the TV) is only about 17".  The brackets are about 12" apart which only gives you about 4-5" of total adjustment which wasn't enough to center it on the wall.  Compare that to one I bought 10 years ago and the plate is much larger (top one in photo).  I wound up using this one because I could slide the TV left or right until it was centered on the wall.There is a work around, you could mount two horizontal 2x4's to the wall and then mount the TV mount to them where ever you want and center it.  This, however, would push the TV out another 1 1/2" from the wall and wouldn't be a clean of an install, even though it would be hidden behind the TV.

reviewTitle: Won’t fit most studs/walls + shipped used product
reviewDescription: First off if you own a typical American home with 16” spacing between studs this product most likely is not possible/feasible to mount on your walls. Longer explanation below At the holes widest points they are exactly 16” apart, However this leaves you no wiggle room whatsoever, to the point that you need to precisely consider the width of the screw when drilling the hole because again at its WIDEST point it’s 16” meaning if you account for the width of the screw you have closer to 15.5” of space between the holes. Most walls are not constructed so that the studs are placed at exactly 16”, there is a good chance you will have some studs that are spaced wider than 16” apart. If the spot you want to mount this in is like this, you will have to find a different spot and search around your house for studs that are lucky enough to be spaced just right for this product. Seriously, what were they thinking?? It’s clearly a design flaw.Second, this product was clearly used and returned before it was sent to me. Some of the parts were modified in such a way that if you had certain sized screw holes you would have a difficult time. The labeled bags were just left open so the parts could shake around the box, meaning I had to go through the process of figuring out which part corresponds to each letter/number. Also the mount itself was scratched up. I paid for a new product not a used one. Why was I shipped this?TLDR, if you want a used product with obvious design flaws that you can’t actually mount your tv with, then go ahead and waste your money like I did
It was probably a good purchase, however change my mind into not using it. Could not mount on wall.

My package was delivered opened. The seal was broke and the box was partially ripped. I am unable check until this weekend to make sure all of the parts are there, will update after. First time I have ever had an opened package delivered.

reviewTitle: Very narrow, definitely measure stud distances before you buy
reviewDescription: I’ve installed plenty of wall mounts, and I’ve never seen one so narrow. MEASURE your stud width in the spot you want to hang it before you buy.Typically, the 16” specification on a wall mount means that the center-to-center distance in the outside slots is 16”. This is to allow some wiggle room for slight variations in stud-to-stud distance, and so you don’t have to be so dead on with placing the lag bolts. As you can see from my crude drawing, this mount measures 16” from the EDGES of the slots, leaving no wiggle room at all. Everything has to be dead on. So even if you think your studs are 16” apart, it still can be tough to install this mount.That being said, the range of motion is pretty good and sits pretty flush against the wall for being a swing arm style. It doesn’t hold tilt position too well and is a little too easy to knock the roll position off.(Note: Search online for tips on how to find studs from outlets, it’s the first thing I do before trying a stud finder, which I use as a confirmation tool more than an initial finder - it’s thrown false positives).

reviewDescription: This product does not support 65" tv. The mounting brackets you screw on the back of your tv cannot be more than 15" apart. Mine are 25" apart. Had to do Amazon return instead and now I have 4 large lag bolt holes in my wall.

But mounting on a standard Sheetrock wall w wood studs is an issue because the mount is only 16” wide... so if you want to center it, like over a mantle, it's impossible unless your studs magically are in the correct location. The mount needs to be wider so you can center and still hit studs to the left or right. In my case I centered it over the mantle and was lucky that a stud to the left was in range, but on the right I had to add anchors to the Sheetrock, which according to the manufacturer you’re not supposed to do. Luckily my 40” HD LED TV, is not too heavy so hopefully no issues. Also no included instructions and crappy online instructions. I have no idea what 80% of the included hardware was for and I consider myself to be very handy. It is a solid device but should be a minimum of 24” wide.

Comes with helpful template for installation and lots of fasteners, but I ended up buying my own because I didn't trust the ones that came with it (I wanted more heavy duty fasteners). Very easy to install, good instructions. Only issue is that the absolute widest mounting holes are 16 inch or slightly under. If your studs are off a little bit it'll be a challenge to install. Other than that it works great.

There is only one thing that is preventing me from giving this product 5 stars. As I was attempting to put the brackets on the back of me TV, I found the screws I was provided were not long enough. I have a 50 inch Samsung led smart tv (2014 model).The mount is very heavy and sturdy. I have read other reviews stating the hinges on the mount are too stiff. I worked them back and forth prior to installing it on the wall and they are just fine. Easily swivels around. I am happy with this product and I hope it holds up for a long time. Very easy to install.

reviewTitle: Works absolutely great, but the stencil was off by 1/8th of an inch.

Not by much, and luckily when I used the stencil I was still about to use the mount, but just barely.So it works fine, but I gave them 4 stars because the stencil isn’t perfect. Quality hardware and heavy duty construction - no sagging of any kind.Only negative is it is still stiff to pull in/out, but easily rotates. I guess it’s better for it to be stiff so it does not drift, but would think it would be easier to move.  Might be the LG TV is just too weak and flexes when I pull on edges..... reviewTitle: Very nice and well made support in economy category
reviewDescription: First of all it is very good support. It mounted well and with no hiccups although the wall plate is just barely big enough for the 16" spaced studs and TV brackets are barely big enough for the 400x400 VESA. No issues with any of that but if you have anything even remotely out of spec you'll be in bad luck.I also have an Echo mount for my other TV and the difference between them lays in minor details. The functionality is the same and the quality is very similar but Echo has a few more touches like covers for the lag screws that attach the bracket to the wall and cable hangers instead of Velcro ties only. I also prefer Echo 1-screw leveling system over 4 screw one on this one. The one here gives you more options but if you need them you probably did something really wrong when mounting the wall plate.All of these are minor differences but if the bracket can be seen from certain angles with your installation I'd go with Echo, otherwise Mounting Dream is a way to go.

First thing to do is throw away the included level....the one I received wasn’t accurate.  I used one of the levels I already had.  I took the arm portion off from the wall plate before mounting to the wall.  Just too difficult to mount unless you’re just dealing with only the plate.  I had trouble locating studs inside my stucco wall (I mounted this on an outside patio wall).  So I used 6 lag screws and 6 wall anchors (2 of the lag screws and 6 of the wall anchors were not included).  It’s very firmly in place.  After getting the wall plate attached to the wall, I reattached the arm mechanism.  Once that was done, I attached the TV.  I mounted this unit 8 ft up the patio wall.  Fortunately I have a Genie Lift that made it easier to put the TV in the exact, necessary location to attach to the mount.  Overall it’s a well made unit and VERY economically priced.  Would highly recommend.

reviewTitle: Very nice mount with very minor issues
reviewDescription: I am using this mount in my bedroom with a new Sony 850D 55" so I needed some options for viewing my new TV and needed some tilting to angle the screen slightly forward.  This mount is very nice.  The bags with all the hardware isn't clear enough to differentiate the wall mounting supplies with the tv mounting supplies.  Once I realized I was using the wrong screws, the mounting went by quick.Pros: - The quality is high with this one.  The metal feels strong and this has some good weight to it.  When I was tightening the bolts with a socket wrench, I saw no flex or warping in the metal around the bolt which shows serious strength. - The articulation is very nice.  It swivels up, down, left right.  It can pull almost a foot away from the wall.  It can tilt.  Perfect. - There is NO wiggling in the mount itself.  Any wiggles are from my TVs plastic itself. - The box provided a plethora of hardware.  I have SO many extra bits that I don't need so my tool box received a nice deposit.Cons: - The tilting function requires an allen wrench which is annoying.  It would be better to include a hand crank bolt of some design.

reviewTitle: Great mount for the price, but very stiff to extend
reviewDescription: Great mount for the price.  It's very secure, solid, doesn't sag or droop with my 50" TV extended out.  The design is such that with the TV mounted correctly it's very secure and cannot fall with the locking bolts engaged.  I have only one complaint.  The mount is very stiff to pull out.  I bought a TV to just fit in a media nook and built a cabinet below and put shelving above.  It looks great, almost built in, but I only have 1/2" above and below and 1.5" on either side.  To pull the TV out I have to grab it by the edges, and it takes significant force to extend the mount out, so much so that the TV starts to bow, causing concern that I could damage it.  I'd like to know if there's some way to adjust/lubricate the mount to make it easier to extend.  There is nothing on this in the instruction manual.  I understand it can't be too easy to move or just vibrations could cause it to move, but it's way too stiff.  Good news is once everything is in place I likely won't touch it, but I'm on the fence about keeping this mount because of the issue.  Still giving it 4 stars because everything else about it is top notch.

reviewDescription: I have no experience with mounting anything to walls. I used this product to put a 38 lb, 55" TV on my wall, and I am not worried about it falling. I saw an issue that some other people had been having where the middle-top part of the mounting mechanism that is bolted to the wall started to bend forward. I think this has to be an installation error, or maybe something that happens overtime because of that. I have not had a problem with this and honestly will be surprised if I do. The bolts that you put into the stud of your wall are thick, and mine feels like even if I pulled on it, isn't going anywhere. I will come back and give this a 5th star in a year, as long as it has not fallen from my wall, which I doubt is going to happen.

(Not sure if that's normal for a tv mount).Need and hex key to tilt up or down.Very rigid sometimes when retracting into or extending it away from the wall, can feel awkward if your in front of people haha, unless you use some finesse and slide it left and right when extending or retracting it, it kinda helps usually.Note/ConNeed a good drill with right socket size as philips bits don't cut it with these big screwsOverall though for what I paid, and the fact that my 55 inch 4K Samsung didn't fall off my wall and that I can get it to any angle I usually like with very little to no effort makes me happy :) Thanks guys.

reviewTitle: Mostly OK with a heavier flat screen...
reviewDescription: This is the second of these mounts I have purchased and installed.  In addition to these two I have mounted three other televisions on walls.  The latest install with this mount was with a Sony BRAVIA W-Series KDL-52W4100 which according to the purchase info here on Amazon weighs 71 lbs.  This mount is rated for TVs up to 99 lbs so one the surface it seems to be within spec.  I would rate this 5 stars except that the tilting aspect is clearly not strong enough for TVs over I would guess 50 lbs.  I originally had the tilt at just a few (~5) degrees from level.  I took extra time making sure the screws were very tight to avoid it slipping to its maximum.  However, even with that extra precaution the tilt screws were not strong enough and the TV over time tilted to the end of the travel (full 15 degrees down).  To prevent this from happening again I removed the TV, placed bolts in the slots behind the integrated tilt screws to fill the slots and prevent further travel.  This seemed to work fine to secure it.  Also, the TV mounting screws supplied for my bolt size (M6) were either too short or too long.  I had bolts that were in between the supplied lengths on hand from another TV mount that were a better length when used with the supplied stand off plastic spacers and washers.  The 5 mm shorter length was critical to get maximum threads in the mounting holes.  In general with these mounts expect to play around with spacers or shop for other bolt lengths or additional washers.

So I purchased the correct length screws for my TV and not use the spacers. This is a two person job to hang the TV. I also prefer a sturdier connection of tv braces to wall mount. What this means is that 1) even with perfectly spaced studs, you're hitting the edges. 2) If you got unlucky like I did and found the two studs that are a smidge more than 16 inchs OC, then you're drilling new holes in the mount to get proper screw engagement.

reviewTitle: MOUNTING SLOTS ARE NOT ON 16” CENTERS
reviewDescription: At first glance this is a solid, well built unit, and it may work for some. It is not built to American standards as the center of the mounting slots is at 15.25”, not 16”. When you locate a wall stud, you’re actually finding the nail or screw that goes into it, not the wood itself. Because of this, when you mark a stud, you may be off center by almost an inch, worst case, so you need a bit of wiggle room , which is why there are slots and not holes. After very carefully marking my stud centers, the template slots were just barely lined up with the stud centers, with absolutely no wiggle room if my center was slightly off. Sure, it’s possible to shoot the screw in at an angle, but that’s not the best way to ensure that my 40 pound television stays up on the wall where it belongs. I’ve mounted many tvs in my life and know what I’m doing, and it rankles me to no end when products like this are sold with major design flaws. I sent mine back.

reviewTitle: Premium Articulating TV Wall Mount at Discount Rack Price - Buy with Confidence
reviewDescription: At this price point, my expectations were fairly low for the Mounting Dream MD2380 articulating TV wall mount bracket. Much to my surprise, this wall bracket is a robust, well engineered, quality piece that is on par with similar TV wall mounting brackets costing 3 or 4 times as much. The instructions are simple and clear, and the whole installation process is very straight forward. MD even includes a bonus bubble level, a braided 6' HDMI cord, and enough machine screws and spacers to fit the TV mounting brackets to practically any TV on the market. It took me a little over 20 minutes from opening the package to having my 55" 4K TV securely mounted to the wall.The unit is designed to allow you to adjust your TV to sit flat against the wall (with an approx. 3" space) or pull it over two feet from the wall for angling. When extended, the TV can be angled left or right up to 35 degrees and you can also adjust the vertical picture angle from +5 degrees to -15 degrees. An added bonus is the articulation makes it MUCH easier to add components to your TV at a later time. Flat wall mounts require you to remove the entire TV to access the back panels. The unit feels very sturdy and can be moved with a nominal amount of effort. The packaging says this wall mount is rated to hold up to 100 lbs., but when mounted properly, my guess is it could handle at least twice that weight with ease.I highly recommend this product and I am writing this review because I came back here to order two more for our other flat panel TVs. If you are going to buy this wall mount, and trust me, you won't regret it, read on for a brief primer on how to install it.Installation experience: Before opening the box, you will need a cordless drill/driver, a 3/8" drill bit, a measuring tape, pencil, a ratchet with a 12mm socket, a #4 phillip's head screw bit and a stud finder. The instructions say you can mount this bracket to sheet rock studs or cinder block, but not to straight sheet rock. Makes sense as even with sheet rock anchors, the bracket will eventually pull from the wall if the articulation function is used as intended. The first step is to locate what wall you want to mount the TV to and then use your stud finder to locate the studs that you will be anchoring the bracket to. I found that the easiest way to get a nice level mounting was to use the mounting template with the included bubble level. Once level, simply tape the template in place and then drill the four mounting stud holes right through the template. After removing the template, place the wall bracket against the wall, line up with one of the upper holes you just drilled and use your ratchet and socket to drive the first bolt in until it is almost tight. Leave some play so that you can align the other three bolts and do the same with each. When all four bolts are in place, go back and finish tightening them securely. Attaching the TV brackets is really easy with the plethora of machine screws and spacers included with the kit. Once the TV brackets are attached to the back of the TV, find an assistant (depending upon the weight of the TV - this will be a two person job) and place the TV on the wall bracket. You will here it click in place. There are two included screws at the bottom of the TV brackets which are used to lock the TV to the wall bracket. Make sure these are tightened so you can safely use the articulating feature. Plug in your cables, fire up the TV and Voila! You can now sit back and enjoy your TV from practically anywhere in the room with a perfect picture angle.

reviewTitle: Very well designed, sturdy mounts for just about any TV!
reviewDescription: I've been purchasing Mounting Dream mounts for several years. Started buying them for home use and was so impressed I also began purchasing them for work. Measure the distance between the holes and confirm the mount will support them. Like I said, most should, but you never know.Don't toss the extra screws and washers!  You might need these in the future should you replace your TV. These mounts are so good, I'd guarantee that you will use them with several TVs as long as the stand can support them.Packaging is excellent. Box is sturdy and componets are well packaged so as not to move and bang around in transit. Screws, washers and extenders are all bagged according to type and size in clear packaging, so you can select the ones you need easily.Lastly, it's a small detail, but it's a nice one - you get a free level. Although I have several "pro-grade" levels, I like to use these as they're smaller and can balance them on the arms as a second level. Plus - who doesn't need extra levels once in a while!?In short - Excellent mounts, excellent brand.

reviewTitle: ZERO wiggle room for 16" studs, poor bolt location for mounting
reviewDescription: Once it's on the wall, this is a pretty nice TV mount.  It holds my 55" Vizio just fine and the range is good so I can access the cords and things behind/under the TV more easily.  But, getting it on the wall is a BEAR (at least alone, but that's never stopped me before).First, if you have 16" studs, you have to get this thing dead center because there is barely 16" between the leftmost edge of the furthest left mounting hole and the rightmost edge of the furthest right mounting hole. The same goes if your TV mounting bolts are 400mm wide, you'll have about a half inch of play on either side of the mounting bracket to get the TV locked in.  I had to have a neighbor come help me because I couldn't hold the TV and see behind it at the same time to get it just right.  I successfully mounted another 55" TV on a non-full-motion Mounting Dream mount (ASIN B00NKZ5R28) and there was a ton of room for adjustment.Second, good luck using any kind of socket wrench to screw in the lag bolts.  The geniuses put the mounting holes so close to the rest of the frame that I couldn't even get the tip of a normal wrench around it and had to do half turns at a time.  It looks like there's a lot more room in the pictures.  It took me about 5x longer just to screw in the lag bolts for this one than the entire mounting process for the other kind.  That one has the mounting holes inside the frame, so it was easy to use a ratcheting socket and power them right in.Third, which I probably should have realized from the pictures, I'm HIGHLY disappointed that this mount requires unscrewing and screwing in small screws to release and secure the TV, instead of the super-quick and handy pull straps on the first mount I bought.  Mounting Dream, why isn't that standard on all your products???In retrospect, I'll probably be buying a different brand if I ever need another full-motion mount.

reviewTitle: I'd give this 5 stars, had it leveled my TV properly.
reviewDescription: OK, so I'd give this 5 stars, had it leveled my TV properly.Pros:*  This thing is Rock Solid!*  Install is very clear, and easy - once you find the studs.*  They give you a template, so you can mark your drill holes with paper, instead of a heavy mounting bracket.*  All the stuff you need is included - and several options for different TVs is in there, as well.*  It allows for adjustments to the TV from side to side, once mounted (though it affects the distance from the wall)*  It allows for adjustments to the TV tilt angle, so you can aim it towards the floor more, if you mount it high.*  It allows easy access to the back of the TV, once mounted, & easily turns the TV direction left or right.*  It accommodates a number of TV sizes and weights, so it's likely to fit yours.Cons:*  This mount MUST be set into studs on BOTH sides (Just it's own weight would pull it off the wall, otherwise - never mind the added TV weight)*  Adjustments to the TV from side to side, once mounted - affects the distance from the wall - big time. My studs are not centered to the center of the wall, so I was offset by about 8", once mounted. I slid my TV as far towards the center as it could go on their wide mounting bracket, but still had to push the mounting arms to the left by several inches. That forces the TV out from the wall by several inches to get it centered.*  The TV is secured by screws on the bottom, which is good, but there's very little clearance for them, and we nearly stripped one, trying to get it screwed in properly.*  There's no leveling option for the TV mount, once installed. I did mine PERFECTLY, and it is dead level on the wall mount. Unfortunately, once the TV was mounted, it sat crooked - which means the mount arms were not level, even though the mount was level at the wall. THAT is unfortunate, because there's no way in hell to fudge the mount against the wall. You have to bore out huge holes into the studs, just to hold it on the wall, so adjusting it a quarter inch isn't going to happen, and there's no way to know if the arms are level to the mount, until it's too late to fix it.I ended up shimming the top part of the TV bracket, to hold it up higher than it should be. It's not perfect, because I didn't have the perfect metal shim sitting around the house (I stacked 3), so I'm still a tiny bit off level, but it's barely noticeable.For my install, I'm putting it into a bookcase surround, that extends beyond the wall by 11 inches, so the fact that my TV protrudes 8 inches from the wall is not a big deal. I also really like the fact that I can turn the TV to the right or left, and pull it out from the wall to gain access to the back of it.If that protruding thing is an issue for you, then you might want to be sure your studs are centered to where you want to mount the TV. (ie, 8" on either side of where you want the center of the TV to end up, gets you the least protrusion).Overall, I'm very happy with this mount, but the fact that they thought of everything but leveling the actual TV is kinda nutty. It presumes perfection on their manufacturing & assembly, the TV's manufacturing & screw placement, and the homeowner's installation skills. That's a lot of perfection to count on.
